snippet: Labor-backed candidates are on the verge of taking over the city, but experts say unions will still probably not be able to get everything they want.
abstract: Organized labor is having its moment in New York City, as labor-backed candidates win in both Democratic primary for comptroller and runoff for public advocate; experts, however, warn that unions will still most likely find themselves in tough negotiating position, even if Bill de Blasio is ultimately elected mayor, Letitia James become public advocate and Scott M Stringer takes on comptroller job.
lead_paragraph: Labor-backed candidates are on the verge of taking over the city, but experts say unions will still probably not be able to get everything they want.

headline.main: Even With Allies Leading New York City, Unions Won’t Have It Easy
headline.print_headline: Even With Allies Leading City, Unions Won’t Have It Easy
